Posts.Content: Hi... I have an update and it's not very good. :-( The doctor attempted to do the stereotactic biopsy for over 3 hours and finally gave up. I didn’t have it done. My suspicious area is in a difficult place to get to, the machine adjusting to the correct angle, my breasts are so small… they even tried putting my arm in the hole with the breast and rest my arm in a sling to get my breast positioned better…over and over but were not able to get into a sufficient position for the biopsy. And when they finally thought they had a good position, either they couldn't see the calcifications from that angle... or my breasts were so packed like a pancake that it left no room for the needle to go in... not enough breast meat! This stinks! Now I have to have open surgery. Normally when you have breast surgery you have a lump… so they go in and remove it. Since I have extremely tiny microcalcifications… the only way you can see them is thru the xray… So now, I have to see a radiologist right before surgery so he can try and put in a wire to the tip of location, then when in surgery the surgeon will know where to take out… it’s like a needle in a haystack. Dr. said my case is very challenging yet it’s the only way. Can you believe these calcifications are so worrisome… The Dr. showed me the actual area of concern on the images and they are sooo tiny. Caroline... now that you are having surgery... did they put the metal clip in your breast so they know where to go? You now have a marker?

Posts.Content: I am 38 years old. My first mammogram was last year. I had to go back for more pictures for a closer look. But they were round and had a benign apprearance. She said no concern. Case closed and see you next year. Well... here we are next year. Had the mammogram done, again, had to go again for a closer look on the same breast where the microcalcifications are. Met with a different doctor (in the same place). He told me there were a patch of them on top left breast that looked concerning. He can't categorize them as benign or malignant-looking and so had to put them in the undetermined bin. He said "If you were my daughter or wife, I would want you to get a biopsy". He recommended a stereotactic biopsy with a needle, etc. Then... I asked has the pictures/microcalcifacations spots changed since last year's pictures? He said not really. So I asked well then why wasn't this recommended last year to me? He said "different doctor, different opinion". If it's breast cancer... wow... a whole year without having the biopsy done? That seems very odd! I was never alluded to look into the same findings? So now the agonizing waiting for the appt... and then the worst... the results.

Posts.Content: At the age of 36 I felt a rock hard small, moveable, painless lump on my breast. I could have sworn it was bad. When I went to the breast specialist they said my breasts are too dense for a mammogram so they gave me an ultrasound. Immediately they told me it was a cyst.... it was filled with liquid, no solid mass, no branching. And that was that. About a month or so later it started shrinking. I would go with the ultrasound and if they tell you it's a cyst... I would leave it at that. If the ultrasound shows any kind of solidness... next step would most likely be a biopsy.

Posts.Content: CarolineNC - Glad to hear you have got a firm surgery date set. Did you ever ask if tamoxifen was definitely suggested for you? Why would you have to take that if you DON'T have cancer? You are only at a small percentage higher risk of cancer.... but only a small risk...is that of enough warrant to take that drug?? Women who have a relative have BC or test positive for BC gene or have been exposed to radiation in past... they are at even higher risk... when does it stop? You know what is weird... I read that since stereotactic biopsies have become widely used as an easier and less costly way to diagnose... breast cancer has been diagnosed so much more... and some of those diagnosis (especially DCIS and non-cancer hyperplasia) may indeed never ever progress to anything further... but since YOU KNOW you have it... these surgeries and removals and procedures are going up the ying yang! Also... if you were to autopsy every woman who ever died (of other causes)... more and more would actually have breast cancer... but it would never progress. Tell this to a woman and she'd still probably opt for surgery JUST to be reassured... I know I would. But it's interesting to learn that it may not be that uncommon!

Posts.Title: What would you do? Surgical biopsy or 6 month follow-up???

Posts.Content: I had my baseline mammo a year ago... Additional views needed on clustered microcalcifications but doctor said they appeared benign in appearance and to come back in 1 year. This year, same thing... same microcalcifications viewed but different radiologist said they were so tiny, small, fuzzy, and can't tell... labeled them indeterminent and BiRad4 biopsy recommended...although his suspicions were low of cancer. Nothing changed from year ago... his opinion he said was just different. I had an attempted stereotactic 2 months ago but didn't work. Dense breasts, small breasts, calcifications are so hard to find. The next recommendation was excisional surgery biopsy. Met with surgeon. She suggested 6 month follow up? I said but radiologist suggested biopsy?! She asked if they could attempt another stereotactic to avoid surgery. I agreed. That stereotactic biopsy was today. Again, didn't take. Upon many twists/turns/squeezes... they couldn't find the microcalcifications on image because breasts are so small and dense. The only time you can really see them is during a regular diagnostic imaging mammogram. Radiologist suggested 6 month follow-up as she wasn't highly suspicious. But she did say if I wanted to see this through to the end, I would need surgery. I'm 38 years old. No breast cancer history. Yet every grandparent I have has died of another type of cancer. I need a couple days to think about what to do next. This is so hard. On the one hand their suspisions are low. But, they have seen this kind of thing turn up as cancer... at some times. There just isn't a guarantee. Every radiologist/dr I talk to says something different. First radiologist said 80% of biopsied calcifications turn up benign. Today this radiolgist said 90%. I just don't know what to do. I'll start by asking, if it were you... what would you do???

Posts.Content: I have an update from this original post! And still... I don't know what to do??? I have had 2 attempted stereotactic biopsies that couldn't be done due to the fact the microcalcifications are too small/fuzzy and hard to find during certain positions when attempting the biopsy. Breasts are extremely small too. The surgeon told me the only thing next to do to know what this is would be excisional surgery. But she says she and her radiologist feel that the probability/suspicion for cancer is very low and would suggest a follow up mammogram 6 months from the first mammogram (which would be in 2 months) and see if it changes. (funny, that's not what the suggestion was before the failed biopsy attempt). She said cancer doesn't usually lull around and eventually makes changes. And if the next mammogram has any sort of change/growth it can have a better chance of a sucessful biopsy. To make matters more challenging, she said if I opted for the surgery I would have to have the radiologist insert a wire to the tip of the area prior to going under and based on the fact the stereotactics couldn't work, there is a possibility that again, the radiologist won't be able to wire to area and I will not be able to have the surgery! And if that is the case... I will never know what the heck this area is!! Unless...it grows more to see it!? She said she would never open a breast up to take anything out unless it is clearly and absolutely marked where...and that is a challenge in my case. She said the choice is mine and she would be fine with either... attempt the surgery or another mammo in August. I asked if it were her what would she do? She said personally she would mammo it in August to see if there is a change but again, if they were ever wrong... I could have had this taken care of at surgery. I don't know what to do!! I wish I could know if the radiologist will be able to wire it prior to surgery but she said that is impossible until the day of surgery. Looking for opinions....
